question.title: Call to Ceph object gateway returns 400
question.body:
I am attempting to create an object on our Ceph instance and the only piece of information returned is that the request failed with a 400. I don't have direct access to Ceph logs as its managed by the other team, but they were only able to pull a small set of Ceph RGW logs that do not indicate the reason but only state the request completed with a 400.

The client setup is fairly simple:

  public S3Client s3Client(S3Properties s3Properties) {
return S3Client.builder()
    .endpointOverride(URI.create(s3Properties.baseUrl()))
    .region(Region.of(Region.EU_CENTRAL_1.id())) // Not used by Ceph but required by AWS SDK
    .credentialsProvider(
        StaticCredentialsProvider.create(
            AwsBasicCredentials.create(s3Properties.accessKey(), s3Properties.secretKey())))
    .forcePathStyle(true)
    .build();

The put request is also very straight forward:

  var putRequest =
      PutObjectRequest.builder()
          .key(key)
          .bucket(s3Properties.bucket())
          .contentType(contentType)
          .build();

  PutObjectResponse putObjectResponse =
      s3Client.putObject(putRequest, RequestBody.fromBytes(fileContent));

I've validated that the credentials are fine by listing the buckets on application startup. This works. The contentType is generated from the Apache Tika library.

They key is "/attachments/uuid/fileName.ext".

I've played around with removing the forcePathStyle, did not work. The ops team stated they have too much traffic on RGW and cannot enable debug mode. Another interesting hint is that a team that is using the minio library for the client - has no issues without any additional configuration. Not sure how to debug this further.

Locally I have a minio container setup for mocking the s3 storage - everything works as intended.

EDIT: I was able to dig up that the cause is XAmzContentSHA256Mismatch. I'm not sure what is the cause though.

answers.body:
The problem was in the Ceph version vs AWS SDK Version. The Ceph version uses MD5 to generate the checksums, while the AWS SDK uses CRC32 resulting in a checksum mismatch.

The AWS SDK lets you work around this by setting the requestChecksumCalculation field to RequestChecksumCalculation.WHEN_REQUIRED, like so:

    return S3Client.builder()
        .endpointOverride(URI.create(s3Properties.baseUrl()))
        .region(Region.of(Region.EU_CENTRAL_1.id())) // Not used by Ceph but required by AWS SDK
        .credentialsProvider(
            StaticCredentialsProvider.create(
                AwsBasicCredentials.create(s3Properties.accessKey(), s3Properties.secretKey())))
        .forcePathStyle(true)
        .requestChecksumCalculation(RequestChecksumCalculation.WHEN_REQUIRED)
        .build();

79662075.body: Thank you, this fixed my problem! I was also using AWS SDK v2 and Ceph. Enabling debug logging was helpful in seeing the raw HTTP request and response: docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-java/latest/developer-guide/…
